data.title: Top Women in Communications Awards Luncheon
data.meta_description: Feb. 29, 2024 | Come celebrate with Ragan and your peers this year’s lineup of Top Women in Communications. We’re rolling out the red carpet on Thursday, Feb. 29 for a special luncheon at the City Winery in New York City to celebrate the 2024 class of fearless female marketers.
data.text:
Chief Communications Officer

KeyCorp

Susan Donlan: The calm in the storm

Susan Donlan’s work keeping KeyBank on the right course through COVID-19 and other crises has earned her a spot in the Women in Communications Hall of Fame in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards, Class of 2024.

Over the course of her career, Susan Donlan’s influence and impact has blazed the trail for women in the banking industry, in which a vast majority of leadership and board roles are still held by men.

Currently chief communications officer at KeyCorp, a financial services company with assets of approximately $189 billion and more than 17,000 employees, Donlan launched her career working with the government of Canada in research and international policy, as well as advising multiple ministers. She went on to serve in the Canada Revenue Agency and the Office of the Minister of Labor and Housing, laying the foundation of her communications career.

At T.D. Bank, Donlan used her ability to build rapport and relationships to lean further into corporate communications, mastering internal and external communications, executive communications, media relations and crisis communications while ascending through the ranks to the post of vice president in 10 years.

“I have always valued the ability to listen — actively listen,” Donlan told Ragan. “You learn so much when you listen to how people are saying things, what they are sharing with you and how they feel about it. It connects you with your audience and helps you understand them. That makes you a better communicator.”

In 2018, Donlan relocated to the United States to join KeyBank as chief communications officer in Cleveland, Ohio. Once there, Donlan made sweeping changes to the corporate communications team, including establishing a leadership team and affording senior members of her team with development and leadership opportunities. Since then, she has led the team through worldwide crises and historic challenges to the banking industry.

One challenge, of course, was the COVID-19 pandemic, which hit shortly after a CEO transition. Donlan developed a reputation for being the “calm in the storm,” steadily leading her team through the pandemic while ensuring all KeyBank stakeholders were supported. Her efforts included a comprehensive internal and external plan, consumer relief, small business and Paycheck Protection Program support and continued support in the community.

Then came the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank in March 2023. The two largest bank failures since 2008 sent shockwaves through the industry, especially for regional institutions like KeyBank. Donlan mobilized the team with an action plan that supplied employees with essential information, ensuring that clients remained confident in KeyBank’s strength and stability. She also addressed numerous media inquiries and positioned CEO Chris Gorman as KeyBank’s voice in the public.

“I’ve learned how important it is to be the voice of calm within the chaos — even if I’m not feeling that calm on the inside,” Donlan said. “Experience has taught me to focus on how we move forward and out of the crisis instead of worrying about how we got there. There’s always time to reflect back and determine how to learn from a situation once the crisis passes, not from a blame perspective, but from the perspective of how we can do better.”

An active participant in KeyBank’s formal mentoring program, Donlan is involved in the Cleveland community, serving as a director on the Cleveland Museum of Natural History Board and as a member of the Cuyahoga County Public Library Foundation Board.

“The field has changed so much since I began my career,” she reflected to Ragan. “The day of prose memos is long gone — you need to be able to package your content in small, digestible pieces, focusing on what you really need the audience to know. This can be a real challenge when you are dealing with complex information — the ability to synthesize complexity is a more important skill than ever for communicators.”

She advises other communicators to slow down and take time to appreciate where they are and what they’re working on. “I was always in such a hurry to get to the next thing, like I was running out of time,” she said. “Instead of focusing on the next opportunity or role, now I really try to enjoy all of the things I get to do and learn every day in my current role.”

Congratulations to Susan Donlan!

Chief Communications Officer

Kraft Heinz

Kathy Krenger: Iconic work for iconic brands

Kathy Krenger revamped the comms team, beefed up the company’s news engine and boosted communications with employees, earning her spot in the Women in Communications Hall of Fame in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards, Class of 2024.

In 2021, as Kraft Heinz was navigating one of the most visible transformations of the decade, its CEO decided to rebuild the company’s communications team from the ground up. The person he selected to lead that team was Kathy Krenger, prompted by her stellar leadership as senior vice president of global communications at Hyatt Hotels Corporation, where she guided the hospitality brand through one of its most challenging periods amid pandemic lockdowns.

“I also watched as our entire industry collapsed in a matter of days,” Krenger said of her experience at Hyatt. “Even now, when I look back at how volatile those first few months were, I can hardly believe it was real. But the work we were doing then was vital, critical, even ground-breaking. People needed our communications. They needed the information we created to survive. And sometimes, the content we were developing was the only thing giving them hope. I know this sounds a little dramatic today, but in that instant it was true.”

Building upon that experience, Krenger joined Kraft Heinz as chief communications officer. Her task: Take what had been a small support function within the company and create a best-in-class global center of communications to serve as a strategic partner to the business.

Two major initiatives demonstrate Krenger’s work boosting Kraft Heinz’s reputation:

From 2022 to 2023, Krenger’s team increased annual corporate media coverage results by 265%. In addition, negative news coverage decreased to 9% (down from 31% in 2021), with 91% of media coverage positive to neutral. Kraft Heinz ranked No. 28 in the 2023 Axios Harris “100 Reputation Rankings,” moving up the list from 2022 (and not making the list at all in 2021).

And when employees reported feeling overwhelmed and disconnected from each other and their leaders. In response, Krenger’s communications team launched a new, mobile-enabled engagement platform, “The Vine,” to deliver timely and easily accessible information to the company’s 37,000 employees. To date, 97% of users have engaged on the platform, and a recent employee survey showed that 80% of respondents have greater trust in information coming from the company.

She told Ragan that an underrated quality for communicators to master is the ability to “read the room… and pivot the conversation based on someone’s preferences or need for clarity. It’s easy to forget that you may have spent the last two weeks focused on this topic, but your audience has not. They need time to absorb, ask questions and understand how this conversation or topic impacts them and if you are able to see their pause as an opportunity bring them along on the journey, be comforted by your understanding of all sides of the issue, you will have a partner and advocate rather than a detractor.”

She also touted the importance of writing skills. “Now more than ever, words matter,” she said. “Connected to words, I believe the ability to influence is a critical skill for communicators. Senior communicators will often find themselves being the one person in the room with a contrary position. Being able to explain your position without sounding like a dream killer is key.”

Thanks to Krenger’s efforts, the team today consists of 55 internal and external communication professionals across 15 countries. The team manages internal and external communications media relations, executive thought leadership, crisis and issues management, creative content generation and much more for the company.

“In an era where everything is about reputation management, and where there are pitfalls and opportunities at every turn, [Krenger] has elevated the communications function to be a go-to partner to guide company actions that span far beyond traditional communications practices,” says Alex Abraham, vice president, global corporate communications and reputation management at Kraft Heinz.

“Know yourself so you can believe in yourself,” Krenger advises. “I spent far too much time lamenting as to why I wasn’t the star of or the best at X, Y or Z. I wish I had really leaned into my strengths more, stopped worrying about other people and what they were doing and learned how to use my strengths as my superpower.”

Congratulations to Kathy Krenger!

Senior Vice President, Global Communications

Philip Morris International

Marian Salzman: Redefining the future

Marian Salzman spread the word ‘metrosexual’ and boosted #GivingTuesday. At Philip Morris International, she combats misinformation and hate, putting her in the Women in Communications Hall of Fame in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards, Class of 2024.

Marian Salzman’s career has always focused on the future — and she has consistently shaped that future. In the early 1990s, when the internet was still considered the domain of nerds, she founded the world’s first cyber-consultancy — holding online focus groups via her startup, American Dialogue, also known as Cyberdialogue.

It’s no exaggeration to call her a cultural icon: she helped introduce the word “metrosexuality” to the world in 2003, sparking a global media frenzy that ultimately resulted in “metrosexual” being named Word of the Year.

“People radar matters a lot,” Salzman told Ragan. “You can accomplish anything when you surround yourself with the best people, and when you work for and with people who are smarter than you are, and who share your commitment to great work, and good fun.”

And Salzman was a driving force behind #GivingTuesday, which encourages consumers to offset the gluttony of Black Friday and Cyber Monday by helping others and raising tens of billions of dollars for community programs.

In a PR career spanning three decades, Salzman has served as CEO of Havas PR North America and chair of the Havas Global PR Collective. In 2018 she moved to Philip Morris International (PMI) as senior vice president, global communications, to help the company deliver a smoke-free future.

Salzman guides PMI’s communications, media and other stakeholder engagement, forging productive alliances with NGOs, advocacy groups, policymakers and others. The end goal: making it easier for adult smokers to move away from cigarettes and toward the better science-based alternatives now available.

Using her global platform to combat misinformation, promote transparency and advance positive change, Salzman sparks conversations around important issues via her annual trends report, newsletter and PMI whitepapers — including “Hate Is in the Air,” a report that dissects the drivers of hate and challenges companies to contribute to solutions.

She says curiosity and energy are the most important skills for communicators. “If you aren’t in continuous learning mode, you will quickly be left behind.” She lives out that advice herself: Salzman told Ragan that she was taking remote courses in government at Johns Hopkins University when the pandemic began. “This engagement gave me a whole lot of brainfood at a time when socialization was largely screen-based. I developed considerable expertise by going back to school thirty-odd years after I had completed my formal education, and this made me a much better leader and professional. Studenting also knocked any arrogance I had right out of my system.”

As a commentator for a range of global and national media outlets, Salzman has been featured on the BBC, NBC News, Euronews, Sky News and Bloomberg Radio, as well as podcasts like Andrew Yang’s “Forward.” She also regularly serves as a keynote speaker or panelist at such venues as GWPR VOICE, IAA Creativity 4 Better Conference, University of Notre Dame’s Mendoza College of Business and more, and is the author or co-author of 18 books.

Her advice to rising communicators: “Go abroad frequently, work there feverishly, savor the friendships you made in the early days because at the end of a career, it is the experience collecting, the human relationships, that carry you forward and make you better and more able to face the challenges day-to-day. I also wish I had become addicted to Pilates earlier, had embraced casual dress sooner, and would have dreamed as big as life carried me. I always treasured the journey and picked bosses but never planned my career, so I wish I would have known how lucky I would be — that would have made it easier to relax more, to worry less, and to have confidence that I would never have to compromise ‘me’ to succeed in the world of ‘we.’”

Congratulations to Marian Salzman!

Vice President, Chief Communications and Marketing Officer

SPX FLOW

Melissa Buscher champions employees, women and the community at SPX FLOW

The TV reporter turned corporate communicator, Melissa Buscher, supports her employer, women and the community, making her a true Bridge Builder in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

Melissa Buscher spent 15 years as an award-winning television reporter before shifting gears to a career in corporate communications and marketing. As chief communications and marketing officer at SPX FLOW, she fills one of six senior leadership roles in the company as the only woman in the group. Buscher is focused on supporting others, whether it’s promoting her team’s work, championing women or improving the lives of people in her community.

For instance, Buscher learned from production workers at SPX FLOW’s global manufacturing sites that employees didn’t know how their products were being used. To bridge that knowledge gap, Buscher created a campaign, “Solution City,” to show employees and external stakeholders how the parts employees produce play a role in everyday life; this ultimately led the company to start referring to employees as Solution Makers.

Buscher also transformed the marketing team into strategic partners instead of mere order takers. Under her direction, marketing became a major revenue generator for the company — one marketing event, for example, brought in $10 million in business opportunities.

She’s created blogs and podcasts to help employees hear more from leaders, improving transparency throughout the company. In addition, Buscher uses her network to make connections, referrals and introductions between people, to ensure everyone around her has the opportunity to maximize their potential.

Community service also plays an essential role in her life. Buscher is currently the chair of the board of advisors for Designed for Joy, a nonprofit providing stability to women in crisis through immediate employment and support. She is also a marketing committee member for A Place at the Table, a pay-what-you-can restaurant supporting people experiencing homelessness. Beyond that, she sits on the board of advisors of United Partnerships, an organization that collaborates on initiatives that lift individuals, organizations and communities with focus areas including workplace culture, employee resource groups, community engagement and collaboration.

She is also an advocate for DE&I and is passionate about mentoring and sponsorship. Buscher serves as executive sponsor for SPX FLOW’s BEGIN, an employee resource group for young professionals. Before that, she was the executive sponsor for EMPOWER, an employee resource group dedicated to empowering women. In addition, Buscher is a regular guest speaker and mentor for SPX FLOW’s women’s leadership program.

Congratulations to Melissa Buscher!

Vice President of Global Marketing and Global Brand Owner

Berry Global, Inc.

Laci Hasenour champions sustainability in the plastics industry at Berry Global

At Berry Global, Laci Hasenour developed a vast campaign to convince the industry and its customers to do ‘More Together’ to reuse and recycle their products. She’s a Bridge Builder in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

Three years ago, Laci Hasenour brought her 14 years of sales and marketing experience to Berry Global, a manufacturer and marketer of plastic packaging products. As vice president of global marketing, Hasenour runs worldwide marketing and communications for 40,000 employees across more than 250 locations and has helped transform 47 companies acquired by Berry into a single, global brand.

One of Hasenour’s major accomplishments has been developing Berry’s “More Together” initiative — a campaign to educate Berry employees, customers and partners about creating positive change by collaborating across the plastics value chain.

Hasenour and her team spent 11 months developing the design, communications and corporate brand teams deployed in the campaign. “More Together” was launched in November 2022 at Chicago’s Pack Expo. Among all 2,221 digital showrooms at the expo, the booth Hasenour helped design scored the top 5 ratings across all five sustainability categories. The 2,500 views of the booth resulted in 944 unique leads, a 352% increase in recorded interactions, along with 1,494 unique contacts.

Under her leadership, Berry’s external communications team created joint communication plans supporting “More Together” in collaboration with Wendy’s, McCormick, Heinz and many more companies. The initiative’s success ultimately made it the theme for the company’s 2022 annual ESG report.

In addition, Hasenour created a campaign calling on all Berry employees to ask customers and partners one simple question: “What’s your more?” By encouraging people to share their “more,” Berry can identify and listen to the people’s commitment to sustainability, helping the company turn insights into actions that help keep resources in use and out of our environment.

Congratulations to Laci Hasenour!

Vice President, Internal Communications

Cognia

Kimberly Leidgertwood keeps the past and future connected at Cognia

Kimberly Leidgertwood edits the company newsletter, preserving its history and helping employees succeed. She’s a Bridge Builder in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

Throughout her 30+ year career, Kimberly Leidgertwood, vice president of internal communications at Cognia, has been an advocate of the employee. That means working with leadership to ensure that perspectives from the workforce get shared upward while also serving on cross-functional teams, employee resource groups and task forces to expand the reach and role of internal communications.

As the editor of the company newsletter “Connections,” Leidgertwood gathers leads throughout the organization to publish timely news, getting ahead of concerns and suggesting topics for the CEO’s editorial piece. In the past year, her guidance has led to a spike in readership with over a 70% open rate and consistent positive feedback. She also serves as the organization’s historian, taking responsibility for archiving and preserving Cognia’s history.

Leidgertwood also spearheaded the launch of Cognia’s Reference Library, a living repository of all the resources, documents and tools the marketing and communications team creates to support internal staff. She took on the project after realizing employees were having difficulty locating the information they needed to do their jobs.

In addition, Leidgertwood serves as liaison to Cognia’s board of directors, supervising the delivery of its quarterly report and biweekly newsletter. Board members recognize Leidgertwood as a steady leader with her finger on the pulse of the organization.

“As my manager,” says one of Leidgertwood’s direct reports, “Kimberly has created a myriad of opportunities for me to learn from her, enhance my communication skills and reach my professional goals. Beyond the work, Kimberly has become a trusted confidante and mentor. She is the leader that I aspire to emulate because she simply has that personal touch that separates the good from the great.”

Congratulations to Kimberly Leidgertwood!

Chief Communications & Public Affairs Officer

Beyond Finance

Yolanda Schufford goes above and beyond at Beyond Finance

Yolanda Schufford is protecting consumers by educating the public and influencing policymakers about debt issues, making her a Bridge Builder in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

Debt resolution company Beyond Finance is dedicated to helping clients achieve financial freedom and promote sound policy in an industry regulated at the federal and state levels. As chief communications and public affairs officer, Yolanda Schufford oversees its corporate communications (internal and external), public affairs and government relations — as well as managing lobbyists in key states while sharing information and fighting misinformation with policymakers and regulators.

The firm offers group and individual financial counseling to help people significantly reduce their debt. Beyond Finance works with psychotherapists and analysts to help media, policymakers and consumers understand the mental and physical impact of “financial PTSD.” Schufford’s media and public information campaigns educate both the public and policymakers about how debt resolution helps people.

Schufford is also focused on protecting consumer rights. She was instrumental in helping stave off potentially restrictive legislation in debt resolution programs for North Carolina consumers. She also helped transform potentially harmful policies in California. In New York and New Jersey, Schufford was part of a team that introduced a model bill designed to initiate positive industry legislation.

During Schufford’s tenure on the executive team, Beyond Finance has grown its internal outreach from 400 employees to more than 1,500 across 49 states. Externally, her focus has been growing the company as a new brand in a niche market; as a result, Beyond Finance has grown into one of the country’s largest and most influential debt resolution organizations.

Outside her role at Beyond Finance, Schufford also serves on the board of an industry trade association, the American Fair Credit Council, and two nonprofits: Women of Debt Relief and Mentoring Brother2Brother.

Congratulations to Yolanda Schufford!

Vice President of Corporate Affairs

Royal Canin North America

Talk to the animals: Racquel White forges connections between pets, humans and Royal Canin North America

At Royal Canin North America, Racquel White’s efforts have supported animal adoption, vet care and more, while also celebrating her community. She’s a Bridge Builder in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

Racquel White is in a unique point of connection for pet owners, industry partners and Mars, Inc. brands. As vice president of corporate affairs for Mars subsidiary Royal Canin North America (RCNA), which specializes in the health and nutrition of dogs and cats, White oversees internal and external communications, sustainability, regulatory and client experience teams while serving as spokesperson for the Royal Canin brands.

In 2023, White gave Royal Canin’s support to Missouri’s Puppies for Parole program, in which residents of the state’s prisons train rescue dogs to become more adoptable. To celebrate the program’s 7,000th adoption, White and her corporate team highlighted the program internationally through visits by Royal Canin’s global leadership team. White also spotlighted Canine Companions, the leading organization of the American service dog industry, through her team’s PSA, “Help Them Meet Their Match Sooner.”

For cat lovers, Aug. 22 marked National Take Your Cat to the Vet Day. This was the RCNA brand’s tentpole campaign spotlighting preventive health for felines. Because transportation can be a problem for some cat owners, White and her team launched a first-of-its-kind partnership with Uber Pet, providing up to 5,000 rides in 15 cities, encouraging riders to take their cats to the vet.

Internally, White serves as a sponsor for Royal Canin’s TuVoz Associate Resource Group (ARG), guiding its mission of building a Hispanic community that celebrates individual nationalities while recognizing the union of language and heritage. In this role, White advocates for diverse associates joining the company and her team at all levels through her connection to The LaGrant Foundation, which supports increasing the number of ethnic minorities in communications-related fields.

White’s commitment to animals extends to her personal life as well. She’s written a children’s book series, “My Adoption: A Max Brown Adventure,” in honor of the rescue and adoption story of her dog Max. Meanwhile, she serves on the board of directors for the Moses White Foundation, supporting underprivileged populations in Tampa, Florida, through scholarships and revitalization initiatives.

Congratulations to Racquel White!

Senior Director, Communications

Macmillan Learning

Marisa Bluestone wrote the book on crisis response at Macmillan Learning

Marisa Bluestone’s crisis manual lays out the rules for responding to any crisis. She’s a Crisis Navigator in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

Macmillan Learning’s mission is to inspire every learner with possibilities amid the continued debate on the value and cost of content, the growth of open educational resources, data privacy concerns and legislation seeking to control the content allowed in K12 and college courses. As senior director of communications at Macmillan Learning for the past five years, Marisa Bluestone’s mission has been to help the company adapt to the changing needs of educators, students and institutions.

In 2023 Bluestone set out to create a new, more focused process and policy for responding to crises that threaten its brand and reputation. If a crisis occurred, Bluestone knew the company would need all its stakeholders to be ready, so she worked closely with executive leadership to develop a crisis manual for the organization.

The manual established basic processes and media policies for employees to follow in navigating crises when they strike. Bluestone also created test cases for every department, illustrating how the plan should be implemented and what results to expect. She then met with each team to train employees on the new crisis processes and procedures.

Bluestone put her work into action to protect Macmillan Learning and its brand against 2023’s challenges. Whether confronting a major crisis or a small issue, she was able to quickly coordinate the company’s teams for the right response and achieve a positive result, using each crisis as an opportunity to review and revise the plans for the future.

Bluestone made a difference in the company’s ability to act and respond quickly to any crisis. Just as important, her work has made a positive impact on relationships with employees, stakeholders, and customers.

Congratulations to Marisa Bluestone!

OneTrust

Amid ongoing crises, OneTrust’s Kristy Campbell kept her cool

OneTrust endured a stream of negative events in 2023, but Kristy Campbell guided the company into positive territory. She’s a true Crisis Navigator in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

Kristy Campbell and her team had a busy year in 2023. As chief communications officer at OneTrust, a privacy and security software provider, she was in charge of handling the company’s response to whatever crises may arise.

For example, after a substantial workforce reduction in 2022, the company faced a crisis early in 2023 when an M&A deal was abruptly halted, leading to the layoff of another 200 employees. The reduction drew lots of attention, resurfacing the layoff news from the previous summer. Campbell and the two other members of her team had to swiftly devise comprehensive strategies to manage both internal and external narratives and keep the company’s reputation intact.

In February, OneTrust’s CEO was hit by a surprise lawsuit from two board members and investors. Campbell’s team had to navigate the complex legal and reputational challenges to keep employees focused and limit the headlines. The team’s strategy to keep pumping out product stories and amplify positive news successfully pushed the lawsuit headlines to the third page of Google search.

Then, in March, the M&A cancellation of the previous year caused a string of customer contracts to be revoked. Campbell and her team orchestrated the transition to a new vendor at OneTrust’s expense to ensure that customer relationships remained intact and negative news didn’t erupt on social media or in the press.

August 2023 brought a complex product incident. Campbell and the team had to master the regulatory and legal requirements limiting what the company could share with customers. The balancing act of providing daily updates while protecting certain kinds of information was a challenge, but the team effectively guided the company through the turbulent period.

Through their highly targeted media relations work, the team dominated share of voice (SOV) among competitors in data privacy, substantially increasing SOV quarter over quarter. Positive media coverage in 2023 soared, and negative coverage declined by over half.

Congratulations to Kristy Campbell!

System Vice President Public Relations and Content Strategy

CommonSpirit Health

Gina Czark jumps into action during ransomware attack at CommonSpirit Health

CommonSpirit Health wanted to minimize the media fallout from the attack. Gina Czark took control of the narrative, making her a Crisis Navigator in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

Gina Czark has slept near her cell phone since her early days as a journalist and PR executive. When a call came before sunrise on Oct. 3, 2022, she sprang into action. Her employer, CommonSpirit Health, had just fallen victim to a ransomware attack.

CommonSpirit Health is one of the largest nonprofit health systems in the country, and the attack had the potential for a $160 million impact. Czark had to get briefed, devise a strategy to communicate accurate information to stakeholders, align a fragmented communications team, manage an onslaught of questions and report regularly to leaders.

Her first big decision was answering the key question all communicators face in a crisis, changing moment by moment: How much can we say? During daily meetings, Czark counseled executive leaders and the legal team to limit communications to the minimum necessary while she and her team wrote simple media statements, updating them as events unfolded. Her strategy kept the story from going mainstream and gave CommonSpirit a degree of control over the narrative.

Czark also created a centralized communications process: All communications requests had to funnel through her and her team for approval. To manage the hundreds of requests, she held twice-daily review sessions with legal, compliance, IT and other stakeholders. In addition, she established twice daily war room meetings with the leaders of regional communications teams across the country while building a nearly 24/7 communication channel to track, monitor and triage requests.

As a result of Czark’s efforts, the story was barely mentioned in mainstream national news media and didn’t go viral on social media or online forums. The sparse national coverage that did appear fit in with CommonSpirit’s narrative. In the end, CommonSpirit emerged with a more centralized and integrated communications function and a playbook for the next crisis.

Congratulations to Gina Czark!

Director of Communications

Corn Refiners Association

Influential ‘Feeding the Economy’ report is just one priority for Jacqueline Boggess at the Corn Refiners Association

For the Corn Refiners Association, Jacqueline Boggess handles strategic communication, advocacy and CEO support, but wrangling the data into shape for this yearly report is key. She’s a Data Dynamo in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

One of Jacqueline Boggess’ key responsibilities as director of communications for the Corn Refiners Association (CRA) — in addition to crafting and implementing strategic communications plans, contributing to advocacy and offering direct support to the CEO — is CRA’s annual “Feeding the Economy” (FTE) research study.

Every year, Boggess and her team create a “farm-to-fork” analysis to illustrate the food and agriculture sector’s impact on local, state and nationwide economic activity, distributing the data on National Ag Day (March 21) each year. The data is used by policymakers at the national, regional and local levels of government to make important legislative decisions.

For FTE 2023, Boggess used an earned media outreach strategy to target national, policy and trade outlets for coverage. Weeks before the launch of the report, the team placed an op-ed by CRA president and CEO John Bode in Agri-Pulse, a top outlet in the agricultural industry with more than 50,000 unique viewers. The piece used data from the report to offer a unique perspective on the agricultural industry, showing that it has bounced back from major economic setbacks but isn’t yet reaching its full potential due to the U.S. pausing its pursuit of new tariff-reducing trade agreements.

One week before the launch, Boggess and her team shared a press release under embargo, targeting a highly tailored media list focused on national, policy and trade media, offering interviews with the CEO. At the state level, the team conducted local media market outreach, an effort that included targeting CRA priority policymakers’ states and member headquarters locations.

The effort was a success. Earned media for the report exceeded previous years’ benchmarks, generating 61 mentions — a 27% increase from 2022. The media hits drove traffic to the report’s website, with 3,164 unique views and an average visit of two minutes and nine seconds.

Congratulations to Jacqueline Boggess!

VP, Research & Analytics

EvolveMKD

From ‘fake news’ to matters of representation, Alex Christian provides compelling food for thought at Evoke MKD

Alex Christian’s research has grown revenues for Evoke MKD and earned her a name as a thought leader. She’s a Data Dynamo in Ragan’s Top Women in Communications Awards, Class of 2024.

Every single department in Evoke MKD relies on Alex Christian’s research reports, making her an invaluable member of the PR agency’s team. As vice president and head of EvokeMKD’s research and analytics department, she is responsible for measurement, reporting and proprietary research for the agency and all clients, and her duties include evaluating clients’ reporting to identify meaningful metrics and then executing global strategic and thought leadership research on their behalf.

Christian recently launched Evoke MKD’s proprietary research platform, the Evolution of Communication and spearheaded the platform’s case study, “From ‘Fake News’ to ‘News You Can Use’” in February 2023. The case study focused on the relationship between media and media consumers. Evoke MKD surveyed 1,000 media consumers and 500 media professionals to get their thoughts on the media landscape and the importance of traditional and social media and found that “fake news” was the catalyst for a resurgence in media consumption. The research was shared in various arenas, including as a webinar with Cosmetic Executive Women.

Christian also created a research-based thought leadership platform to explore the idea of inclusive and representative beauty. Conducted via focus groups, her research focused on the importance of representation, but it also emphasized that education, intent and execution matter even more while spotlighting the harm that the tokenization of historically non-Caucasian features causes non-white women.

Since her hire, Christian’s department has grown in revenues from $33,000 in 2021 to $1.8M million in 2023. Outside EvokeMKD, Christian authored the recent refresh of the Barcelona Principles 3.0, a widely recognized industry standard for PR and communications measurement and evaluation — solidifying her position as a thought leader and a standout in the PR industry.

Congratulations to Alex Christian!

Vice President, Communications & Community

Andersen Corporation

Eliza Chlebeck opens a window on Andersen’s inclusive culture

Eliza Chlebeck made the intranet accessible to all, brought in more diverse influencers and much more, making her a Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Champion in Ragan’s 2024 Top Women in Communications Awards.

In her five-year tenure at window and door manufacturer Andersen, Eliza Chlebeck, vice president of communications and community, has displayed a consistent commitment to advancing DE&I.

One of her key accomplishments was the launch of the “Circle” intranet. Previously only accessible to office-based employees and in English, Chlebeck was determined to ensure that all employees, including those in manufacturing, had equal access to the information and resources they needed to do their jobs in their spoken language.

Chlebeck and her team implemented the new intranet in 17 facilities and within nine employee resource network groups, bridging gaps between employees. Now accessible via mobile app, the Circle supports 37 languages.
